publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 80.01

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).

seg.seg: ... towards the (good) [thing] they revealed this one with a man's name [= Rūpyāvata]. They point to the glory of kingship (because of) this good si(gn). ...
... of the country. 1. Thereupon the people from Utpalāvatī (greet)ed this boy [named] Rūpyāvata with great performance

[and] (the homage due to) a king. And that [they did] in which way? In [the tune] "Royal [anthem] of Ārśi": They covered the earth with lotus flowers, all around the city they sprinkled perfumed waters,
all the beings have been (busy (?)). They stretched garlanded arches over the streets [and] the market places, [and] put [up] large white sunshades [and thus] stopped the ray[s] of the sun.
[Clad] in (white) garments the om-pronouncers, the Brahmins, said excellent invocations, announcements (?), benedictions [and] auspicious utterances. They made fan[s] with a jeweled handle
[and] (chowries (?)) waiving (?), [and] they carried the treasures into the open. 1. In such a way precisely at the very time of the anointment of this glorious being [= Rūpyāvata] the
great glory [of the city Utpalāvatī] became visible like (in the divine city of the god) Kubera. Thereupon this king Rūpyāvata (endowed) with pure knowledge, mixed with great compassion, with soft

(hand, with sweet (?)) (voi)ce, he [kept] instructing all beings with equal thought [and] with respect for every [being]. Having acknowledged the good behavior of the beings, attentively the great gods,
(the Asuras), [and] the chiefs of the Yakṣas ensured [lit. made] the protection of the country because of the constant performing of ceremonies in that manner. In [the tune] wärṣämpekän:
The seeds [and] the fruits had been (prospering), distresses disappeared for all beings in all places; without working (rice) without bran [and] without husk
(was provided). (The fruit trees always had) mature fruit [and] sweet fruit. The flower trees were ornated constantly with flowers. Without milking the cows gave milk
Die Blütenbäume schmückten sich immerfort mit Blüten, [und] ohne Melken gaben die Kühe Milch.
The flowering trees evermore adorned themselves with blossoms, [and] without milking the cows gave milk.
... this country was always without epidemy. There one could not find any suffering being.

p.note: mänt in the phrase mänt wäknā 'in such a way, thus' is written with double virāma, even though in this manuscript such phrases or compounds are devoid double virāma after the first member. Note also the word-internal (!) double virāma spelling in mā_l\•kluneyo. There are other examples of such word-internal spellings in clusters, esp. in late TB texts.

The meter has 4x25 syllables with the usual rhythm (5|5|8|7). However, in pāda 1a we have an alternative colon division 5|5|7|8. Note that the tune name literary means "the royal one of the Ārśis", which fits with the content of the narrative about a royal celebration.

472 restores a Pt II w(a)wiwār for w(a)wipār from the causative of the root wipā- 'to moisten', followed by 311. However, the direct object is lost, and, what is more, it is more likely in this passage that the form refers to the act of waiving the aformentioned fans (and maybe chowries). The act of perfuming has already been mentioned in line a3.
Four to five akṣaras are missing.
Formally, the 3.pl. Pt II śaśmānt 'they had been growing' does not comply with the remants of the akṣara in front of the lacuna. A better alternative is pyāṣtṣānt 'they became strong'.

ṣārce is otherwise only attested in A 57 a 2 in the phrase ṣārce spānte wätkāltsune 'firmness reliable [and] confident'. In the present context the adverb/uninflected adjective refers to fruits that are always edible and never raw or rotten.

div.p: Edition36. Siegling's personal copy of p. 36.

list.item:

b5 Die Blütenbäume schmückten sich immerfort mit Blüten, [und] ohne Melken gaben die Kühe Milch. 77, 294, 306

a1 %4 /// , (kā)swac cam ; yāmär pākär , oṅk ñomyo : #1b lāntuneṣiṃ , kärparäṃ ; ṣärpseñc cam krant , ṣo(treyā) #1c – – – – a2 %12 /// (y)p(e)yis : 1 || #1d tmäṣ cam rupyāvateṃ śomäṃ utpalāvatṣiñi wrasañ tsopatsäṃ abhisaṃskāryo lāntun(eṣi) a3 (ynāñmuneyo yā)mr-äṃ täm nu mänt wäknā || ārśi-lāñcinaṃ || # rakär oplāsyo ; tkaṃ riyaṃ ṣiraś ; prasar wräntu , snumṣinäs|snumṣinä|(s) a4 %3 (– – – nāṃ)tsuṣ , puk wrasañ : #1a panwar walānās ; ṣontsaṃ orpaṅksaṃ ; wotār ārkyant , wätsyās śāwaṃ ; caṅkär swāñceṃ , koñ-ñäktes|ko|(ñ-ñäktes) a5 #1b (ārkyan)t wsāluyo ; omkāreñ brāmnāñ ; weñār wākmtsaṃ , āvahantu ; ākäs aśiṣ , maṅgalntu : #1c wmārṣiṃ entsālyo ; ārkyant śañinās|śañinā|(s) a6 ; %5 (– – –) – · w(a)wiwār ; rotkar pākär , pāśinās : 1 || #1d tanne wkänyo cami parnontāp wrases abhiṣekṣināṃ praṣtanäk ñäkciyāṃ kube(r) b1 (ñäktes riyann o)ki tsopats kärparäṃ pākär tāk || tmäṣ säm rupyāvate wäl bodhisatveṃ tsopatsäṃ kāruṇaśśäl triwont āṣträṃ knānmuneyo wlyepäṃ b2 (tsaryo swāräṃ ra)keyo poñcäṃ potoyo puk wrasas ṣya wkäṃ pältsäkyo enäsmāṃ wrasaśśi krañcäṃ swārtwlune yomuṣ pältskumäṣ śāwe ñäktañ|ñäkta|(ñ) b3 (asurāñ) yakṣeñi tāśśi tämne wkänyo opṣlyantu sam wāluneyo ypeyis pāṣlune yāmär || wärṣämpeknaṃ || b4 # %5 /// ; (pyāṣtṣā)nt sārmntu , okontu : #1a nakänt ñātsentu ; puk wrasaśśi , puk tkaṃsaṃ : #1b sne wleṣluneyo ; sne psäl sne käs , b5 (klu – – %2 #1c – – – – –) %5 ; (ṣā)rce oko_(TA)|oko , swār oko_(TA)|oko : #1d puṣpavṛkṣäntu ; skamat yetānt , pyāppyāsyo : #2a sne mālkluneyo ; mālk(a)nt ko(w)i , b6 (– – – %3 #2b – – – – –) %5 ; sne wraske tāk , säm ype skam : #2c klopasu wrasom ; mā_(TA)|mā ontaṃ tmaṃ , kälpāl tāk : #2d (– – – – – –)

a1 ... towards the (good) [thing] they revealed this one with a man's name [= Rūpyāvata]. They point to the glory of kingship (because of) this good si(gn). ... a2 ... of the country. 1. Thereupon the people from Utpalāvatī (greet)ed this boy [named] Rūpyāvata with great performance a3 [and] (the homage due to) a king. And that [they did] in which way? In [the tune] "Royal [anthem] of Ārśi": They covered the earth with lotus flowers, all around the city they sprinkled perfumed waters, a4 all the beings have been (busy (?)). They stretched garlanded arches over the streets [and] the market places, [and] put [up] large white sunshades [and thus] stopped the ray[s] of the sun. a5 [Clad] in (white) garments the om-pronouncers, the Brahmins, said excellent invocations, announcements (?), benedictions [and] auspicious utterances. They made fan[s] with a jeweled handle a6 [and] (chowries (?)) waiving (?), [and] they carried the treasures into the open. 1. In such a way precisely at the very time of the anointment of this glorious being [= Rūpyāvata] the b1 great glory [of the city Utpalāvatī] became visible like (in the divine city of the god) Kubera. Thereupon this king Rūpyāvata (endowed) with pure knowledge, mixed with great compassion, with soft b2 (hand, with sweet (?)) (voi)ce, he [kept] instructing all beings with equal thought [and] with respect for every [being]. Having acknowledged the good behavior of the beings, attentively the great gods, b3 (the Asuras), [and] the chiefs of the Yakṣas ensured [lit. made] the protection of the country because of the constant performing of ceremonies in that manner. In [the tune] wärṣämpekän: b4 The seeds [and] the fruits had been (prospering), distresses disappeared for all beings in all places; without working (rice) without bran [and] without husk b5 (was provided). (The fruit trees always had) mature fruit [and] sweet fruit. The flower trees were ornated constantly with flowers. Without milking the cows gave milk b6 ... this country was always without epidemy. There one could not find any suffering being.

a1 /// [s]wac ca_m\• yā_m_ar pā_k_a_r\• oṅ_k\• ñomyo : lāntuneṣiṃ _k_arpa_r_aṃ _ṣ_arpseñc ca_m\• kran_t\ [ṣ]o (– – – – – –) a2 /// (·)p(·) yi_s\• : 1 || _t_m_aṣ ca_m\• rupyāvateṃ śo_m_aṃ utpalāvatṣiñi wrasañä\ tsopat_s_aṃ abhisaṃskāryo [lā]ntu[n](· –) a3 /// – ○ m_r-_aṃ _t_am nu _m_an_t\• wäknā || ārśi-lāñcinaṃ || ra_k_a_r\• oplāsyo tkaṃ riyaṃ ṣiraśä\ pra[s]ar w_r_antu snum[ṣ]i_n_a-\ a4 /// – tsu○ṣ puk wrasañä\ : panwar walānās ṣontsaṃ orpaṅksaṃ wotā_r\• ārkyan_t\• wätsyās śāwaṃ caṅ_k_ar swāñceṃ ko a5 /// (·)[_t_a](\) wsāluyo omkāreñä\ brāmnāñä\ weñār wākmtsaṃ āvahantu ā_k_a_s\• aśiṣ maṅgalntu : wmārṣiṃ entsālyo ārkyan_t\• śañinā a6 /// – ·w· wiwā_r\• rotkar pā_k_ar pāśinā_s\• : 1 || tanne w_k_anyo cami parnontāp wrase_s\• abhiṣekṣināṃ praṣtanä_k\• ñä[kc]iyāṃ kube – b1 /// ki tsopa[t]_s _k_arpa_r_aṃ pā_k_ar tā_k\• || _t_m_a_ṣ _s_a_m\• rupyāvate wä_l\(•) bodhisatveṃ tsopat_s_aṃ kāruṇaśśäl triwon_t\• āṣt_r_aṃ knā[nm]un[e]yo wlye[_p_a]ṃ b2 /// keyo poñcäṃ potoyo pu_k\• wrasas ṣya w_k_aṃ _p_a_lt_s_akyo e_n_asmāṃ wrasaśśi krañcäṃ swārtwlune yomu_ṣ _p_altsku_m_aṣ śāwe ñäkta-\ b3 /// ya○kṣeñi tāśśi _t_amne w_k_anyo opṣlyantu sam wāluneyo ypeyis pāṣlune yā_m_a_r\• || wär_ṣ_ampeknaṃ || b4 /// – ○ n_t\• sārmntu okontu : na_k_an_t\• ñātsentu puk wrasaśśi pu_k\• tkaṃsaṃ : sne wleṣluneyo sne _p_s_a_l\• sne _k_a_s\• b5 /// r[c]e oko swā_r\• oko : puṣpavṛkṣäntu skama_t\• yetān_t\• pyāppyāsyo : sne mā_l\•kluneyo m[ā]l[k]·n_t\• ko(·)i b6 /// [s]ne wraske tā_k\• _s_a_m\• ype ska_m\• : klopasu wraso_m\• mā ontaṃ tmaṃ _k_alpāl tā_k\• [:] (– – – – – –)

a3. mänt in the phrase mänt wäknā 'in such a way, thus' is written with double virāma, even though in this manuscript such phrases or compounds are devoid double virāma after the first member. Note also the word-internal (!) double virāma spelling in mā_l\•kluneyo. There are other examples of such word-internal spellings in clusters, esp. in late TB texts.

a6. [[TG]]: 472 restores a Pt II w(a)wiwār for w(a)wipār from the causative of the root wipā- 'to moisten', followed by [[Schmidt KT 2004]]: 311. However, the direct object is lost, and, what is more, it is more likely in this passage that the form refers to the act of waiving the aformentioned fans (and maybe chowries). The act of perfuming has already been mentioned in line a3.
Gerd Carling, Georges-Jean Pinault, Melanie Malzahn

a1-a2. The meter has 4x14 syllables.

a3-a6. The meter has 4x25 syllables with the usual rhythm (5|5|8|7). However, in pāda 1a we have an alternative colon division 5|5|7|8. Note that the tune name literary means "the royal one of the Ārśis", which fits with the content of the narrative about a royal celebration.

b2. Four to five akṣaras are missing.

b3-b6. The meter has 4x12 syllables, rhythm (5/7).

b4. Formally, the 3.pl. Pt II śaśmānt 'they had been growing' does not comply with the remants of the akṣara in front of the lacuna. A better alternative is pyāṣtṣānt 'they became strong'.

b5. ṣārce is otherwise only attested in A 57 a 2 in the phrase ṣārce spānte wätkāltsune 'firmness reliable [and] confident'. In the present context the adverb/uninflected adjective refers to fruits that are always edible and never raw or rotten.
